WhatÂ is Form I-130? 2025 Update

Â Â 

FamiliesÂ inÂ theÂ UnitedÂ StatesÂ areÂ stillÂ waitingÂ months,Â sometimesÂ years,Â forÂ theirÂ I-130Â petitionsÂ toÂ progress.Â ForÂ many,Â thisÂ delayÂ meansÂ beingÂ separatedÂ forÂ longÂ periodsÂ fromÂ theÂ spouses,Â children,Â andÂ parentsÂ theyÂ longÂ toÂ reuniteÂ with.Â ProcessingÂ timesÂ haveÂ farÂ exceededÂ expectations,Â andÂ frustrationÂ continuesÂ toÂ growÂ as USCISÂ strugglesÂ toÂ clearÂ theÂ largeÂ backlogÂ ofÂ family-basedÂ cases.Â Â 

Â 

Update!Â Â 

OctoberÂ 2025 USCIS I-130Â processingÂ timesÂ forÂ spouses,Â parents,Â children,Â andÂ siblings.Â ThisÂ month,Â weâ€™llÂ takeÂ aÂ closerÂ lookÂ at howÂ longÂ approvalsÂ areÂ taking,Â whatÂ USCISâ€™sÂ latestÂ backlogÂ reportÂ reveals,Â andÂ whetherÂ casesÂ areÂ finallyÂ movingÂ fasterÂ in 2025.Â WhileÂ someÂ categoriesÂ showÂ slowÂ improvement,Â othersÂ remainÂ stuckÂ inÂ delays,Â andÂ weÂ coverÂ allÂ ofÂ thisÂ inÂ detailÂ forÂ you.Â Letâ€™sÂ jumpÂ intoÂ theÂ video.Â Â Â 

USCIS I130Â ProcessingÂ TimesÂ OctoberÂ 2025 â€“ Full UpdateÂ Â Â 

Â Â 

TheÂ I130Â petitionÂ forÂ foreignÂ relativesÂ remainsÂ oneÂ ofÂ theÂ mostÂ importantÂ andÂ emotionalÂ stepsÂ inÂ theÂ familyÂ reunificationÂ process. Â Â 

FactorsÂ affectingÂ I-130Â processingÂ timesÂ Â Â 

ProcessingÂ timesÂ varyÂ dependingÂ onÂ theÂ applicant, butÂ understandingÂ whyÂ helpsÂ setÂ realisticÂ expectations.Â Â 

Â Â 

USCISÂ processesÂ applicationsÂ inÂ theÂ orderÂ theyÂ areÂ received.Â However,Â thereÂ areÂ severalÂ factorsÂ thatÂ canÂ affectÂ theÂ processingÂ time ofÂ yourÂ case.Â YourÂ relationshipÂ toÂ theÂ applicantÂ isÂ theÂ firstÂ importantÂ factor.Â FamilyÂ relationshipsÂ fallÂ intoÂ two mainÂ categories.Â Â Â 

Â Â 

ImmediateÂ relativesÂ of U.S.Â citizens,Â includingÂ spouses,Â unmarriedÂ childrenÂ underÂ 21,Â andÂ parents,Â benefitÂ fromÂ fasterÂ processingÂ becauseÂ visaÂ numbersÂ areÂ alwaysÂ available.Â OtherÂ first-degreeÂ relatives,Â suchÂ asÂ marriedÂ children,Â adultÂ sonsÂ andÂ daughters,Â andÂ siblings,Â mustÂ waitÂ forÂ visaÂ availabilityÂ underÂ theÂ familyÂ preferenceÂ system,Â whichÂ oftenÂ takesÂ years.Â Â Â 

Second, USCISÂ workloadÂ andÂ staffingÂ levelsÂ playÂ aÂ significantÂ role.Â WhenÂ theÂ numberÂ ofÂ applicationsÂ increasesÂ orÂ staffingÂ isÂ limited,Â waitÂ timesÂ inevitablyÂ lengthen.Â SomeÂ monthsÂ seeÂ moreÂ applicationsÂ thanÂ others,Â causingÂ temporaryÂ backlogs.Â AnotherÂ importantÂ factorÂ isÂ theÂ accuracyÂ ofÂ yourÂ application. AÂ completeÂ andÂ well-preparedÂ applicationÂ preventsÂ unnecessaryÂ requestsÂ forÂ evidenceÂ (RFE)Â thatÂ canÂ causeÂ monthsÂ ofÂ delay.Â SubmittingÂ incompleteÂ documentsÂ orÂ formsÂ canÂ causeÂ yourÂ caseÂ toÂ be put onÂ hold.Â Â Â 

Â Â 

TheÂ locationÂ ofÂ theÂ beneficiariesÂ isÂ alsoÂ important.Â TheÂ complexityÂ ofÂ theÂ file isÂ anotherÂ factorÂ toÂ consider.Â ApplicantsÂ withÂ priorÂ immigrationÂ issues,Â criminalÂ records,Â orÂ complexÂ documentationÂ requirementsÂ areÂ oftenÂ subjectÂ toÂ additionalÂ scrutiny,Â whichÂ extendsÂ processingÂ times.Â Finally,Â visaÂ availabilityÂ mostÂ affectsÂ distantÂ relatives.Â TheseÂ applicantsÂ areÂ largelyÂ dependentÂ onÂ theÂ visaÂ bulletin,Â whichÂ determinesÂ whenÂ immigrantÂ visasÂ becomeÂ available.Â ForÂ many,Â theÂ waitingÂ periodÂ appliesÂ notÂ onlyÂ toÂ USCISÂ approvalÂ butÂ alsoÂ toÂ theÂ openingÂ of aÂ visaÂ number.Â Â Â 

Â Â 

How canÂ youÂ checkÂ yourÂ I-130Â processingÂ time?Â Â Â 

YouÂ canÂ checkÂ theÂ estimatedÂ timeÂ forÂ yourÂ caseÂ directlyÂ fromÂ yourÂ USCIS onlineÂ account.Â AfterÂ loggingÂ in,Â goÂ toÂ yourÂ caseÂ summaryÂ andÂ clickÂ on â€œprocessingÂ times.â€Â YouÂ willÂ seeÂ anÂ estimatedÂ timeÂ frame,Â forÂ example, â€œ2Â monthsÂ forÂ aÂ caseÂ decision.â€Â However, notÂ allÂ applicantsÂ willÂ seeÂ anÂ estimatedÂ time.Â ImmediateÂ relativesÂ of U.S.Â citizensÂ mayÂ seeÂ aÂ messageÂ statingÂ thatÂ USCISÂ doesÂ notÂ currentlyÂ provideÂ estimatesÂ forÂ thisÂ category.Â ThisÂ doesÂ notÂ meanÂ yourÂ caseÂ is notÂ movingÂ forwardÂ â€” itÂ simplyÂ meansÂ thatÂ processingÂ timesÂ varyÂ soÂ muchÂ thatÂ USCISÂ cannotÂ publishÂ anÂ average.Â Â Â 

ThoseÂ withoutÂ an onlineÂ accountÂ canÂ alsoÂ checkÂ onÂ theÂ USCISÂ officialÂ website.Â EnterÂ yourÂ formÂ typeÂ (I-130)Â andÂ theÂ serviceÂ centerÂ processingÂ yourÂ file. Since USCISÂ frequentlyÂ updatesÂ serviceÂ centerÂ processingÂ times,Â alwaysÂ readÂ theÂ noticeÂ atÂ theÂ top ofÂ theÂ page.Â InÂ 2025,Â manyÂ family-basedÂ petitionsÂ willÂ beÂ processedÂ underÂ aÂ newÂ Service CenterÂ ProcessingÂ framework, aÂ consolidatedÂ systemÂ thatÂ combinesÂ multipleÂ centersÂ toÂ improveÂ consistencyÂ andÂ speed.Â Â Â 

ThoseÂ withoutÂ an onlineÂ accountÂ canÂ alsoÂ checkÂ onÂ theÂ USCISÂ officialÂ website.Â EnterÂ yourÂ formÂ typeÂ (I130)Â andÂ theÂ serviceÂ centerÂ processingÂ yourÂ file. ForÂ U.S.Â citizensÂ applyingÂ forÂ closeÂ relatives,Â theÂ averageÂ processingÂ time isÂ currentlyÂ approximatelyÂ 14.8Â monthsÂ whenÂ applyingÂ fromÂ abroadÂ andÂ approximatelyÂ 9.2Â monthsÂ whenÂ applyingÂ withinÂ theÂ U.S.Â withÂ Form I-485Â forÂ aÂ changeÂ ofÂ status.Â AccordingÂ toÂ USCISâ€™sÂ latestÂ second-quarterÂ backlogÂ report,Â theÂ averageÂ processingÂ timeÂ forÂ greenÂ cardÂ holdersÂ applyingÂ forÂ theirÂ spousesÂ orÂ childrenÂ underÂ 21 isÂ currentlyÂ betweenÂ 30Â andÂ 35Â months.Â Â 

WhatÂ doesÂ theÂ USCISÂ backlogÂ reportÂ reveal?Â Â 

USCISâ€™sÂ secondÂ quarterÂ 2025Â waitingÂ listÂ reportÂ providesÂ importantÂ informationÂ aboutÂ theÂ agencyâ€™sÂ workload.Â AccordingÂ toÂ theÂ data,Â moreÂ thanÂ 10.3Â millionÂ casesÂ areÂ pendingÂ acrossÂ allÂ forms,Â withÂ family-basedÂ petitionsÂ constitutingÂ aÂ significantÂ portionÂ ofÂ these.Â AlthoughÂ theÂ totalÂ backlogÂ remainsÂ high, USCIS hasÂ madeÂ gradualÂ progressÂ inÂ clearingÂ olderÂ I-130Â petitions.Â TheÂ agencyÂ hasÂ focusedÂ onÂ streamliningÂ digitalÂ processing,Â increasingÂ staffingÂ levels,Â andÂ expandingÂ remoteÂ adjudicationÂ forÂ certainÂ serviceÂ centers.Â However,Â resultsÂ areÂ notÂ uniform.Â WhileÂ processingÂ timesÂ haveÂ decreasedÂ atÂ someÂ centers,Â othersÂ continueÂ toÂ experienceÂ delaysÂ dueÂ toÂ regionalÂ workloadÂ differences.Â Â 

Â 

Family-basedÂ immigrationÂ processingÂ timesÂ byÂ categoryÂ 

Â 

CR1/IR1 (spouseÂ of a U.S.Â citizen)Â processingÂ timesÂ averageÂ 14.8Â monthsÂ forÂ foreignÂ applicationsÂ andÂ 9.2Â monthsÂ whenÂ combinedÂ withÂ statusÂ adjustmentÂ withinÂ theÂ U.S.Â WhileÂ theseÂ figuresÂ remainÂ higherÂ thanÂ pre-pandemicÂ levels, aÂ noticeableÂ improvementÂ hasÂ beenÂ observedÂ sinceÂ theÂ beginningÂ of 2024.Â Â 

Â 

F2A (SpouseÂ orÂ childÂ of aÂ permanentÂ resident) â€“Â ProcessingÂ inÂ thisÂ categoryÂ remainsÂ significantlyÂ backlogged,Â withÂ waitÂ timesÂ rangingÂ fromÂ 30Â toÂ 35Â months.Â AlthoughÂ USCISÂ prioritizesÂ familyÂ reunification, F2AÂ casesÂ continueÂ toÂ beÂ affectedÂ byÂ limitedÂ visaÂ numbersÂ andÂ regionalÂ variations.Â Â 

Â Â 

AdjustmentÂ ofÂ statusÂ â€“Â family-basedÂ Â 

Â 

ForÂ thoseÂ filingÂ I-130Â andÂ I-485Â concurrentlyÂ inÂ theÂ US,Â currentÂ processingÂ timesÂ averageÂ 9Â months,Â representingÂ aÂ moderateÂ improvementÂ overÂ lastÂ year.Â PetitionersÂ benefitÂ whenÂ bothÂ petitionsÂ areÂ filedÂ concurrentlyÂ andÂ adjudicatedÂ together.Â Â 

Â 

Employment-based petitions â€“ comparison with family-based petitionsÂ Â 

ForÂ context,Â employment-basedÂ petitionsÂ tendÂ toÂ moveÂ fasterÂ dueÂ toÂ structuredÂ premiumÂ processingÂ options.Â TheÂ normalÂ processingÂ timeÂ forÂ I140 (employment-basedÂ greenÂ card) is anÂ averageÂ of 7Â toÂ 8Â months, butÂ withÂ premiumÂ processing, aÂ decisionÂ can beÂ madeÂ withinÂ 15Â toÂ 45Â businessÂ days. I-129 (nonimmigrantÂ worker)Â petitionsÂ areÂ usuallyÂ processedÂ withinÂ 3Â toÂ 4Â months,Â andÂ premiumÂ processingÂ isÂ availableÂ withÂ aÂ resolutionÂ withinÂ 15Â days. I-485 (employment-basedÂ adjustment)Â applicationsÂ currentlyÂ takeÂ approximatelyÂ 7Â months,Â dependingÂ onÂ theÂ fieldÂ office.Â Â 

Â 

WhileÂ family-basedÂ applicationsÂ do notÂ haveÂ premiumÂ options,Â theseÂ comparisonsÂ highlightÂ theÂ efficiencyÂ gapÂ USCISÂ facesÂ betweenÂ employmentÂ andÂ familyÂ visaÂ categories.Â 

ForÂ now,Â theÂ bestÂ thingÂ youÂ can do isÂ stayÂ informed,Â followÂ upÂ onÂ yourÂ caseÂ regularly,Â andÂ ensureÂ allÂ documentsÂ youÂ submitÂ areÂ completeÂ andÂ accurate.Â FamilyÂ reunificationÂ canÂ takeÂ time, butÂ understandingÂ theÂ processÂ andÂ theÂ reasonsÂ forÂ delaysÂ bringsÂ youÂ oneÂ stepÂ closerÂ toÂ yourÂ lovedÂ onesÂ â€”Â andthatâ€™sÂ whereÂ thingsÂ standÂ inÂ OctoberÂ 2025.Â
